div.l: Alas oure wardeyn̄ has his palfrey lorn̄
This aleyne forgat bothe mele and corn̄
And was al out of mynde his husbondry
What wilk way is he gane he gan̄ to cry
The wif cam leping outward at a renne
She seid alas he goth into the Fenne
With wilde mares as fast as he may go
Vnthank com̄ on his hand þat band him so
And he that bett̉er shuld haue knyt þe Reyn̄
Alas qᵈuod Iohn Aleyne for cristis peyne
Ley doun̄ thy Swerde and I wil myne also
I is ful swift god wate as a Roo
By goddis saule he shal not ascape us bathe
Why nadde thou putte the capul in the lathe
Il hail aleyne y faith thou is a fonne
Þees celi clerkis han̄ ful fast y ronne
Toward the fenne aleyne and eke Iohn
And whan the mylner saw þᵗat þey wer͗e gon̄
He half a busshel of their͗e flour͗e haþ take
And badde his wif knede therof a cake
He seid I trow the clerkis were afferde
Yit can̄ a Milner make a clerkis berde
For al their art / ye lat hem go their͗e wey
Lo where thei gone lat the children̄ pley
Thei gete him not so lightly be my croun̄
Thees celi clerkis ranne up̄pe and doun̄
With kepe kepe stand stand ossa war þe rer͗e
Gee wightly now and I shal kepe him here
But shortly til it was veray nyght
Þey couth not though þei did al her myght
Þeir capul cacche / he ranne awey so fast
Til in a diche thei caught him at the last
Wery and wete as a best is in the Reyn̄
Cometh celi Iohn and with hym̄ Aleyn̄
Alas qᵈuod Iohn that day that I was born̄
Now ar we dryuen̄ to hethyng ⁊and to scorn
